explanation:
Explain why each symbol is required

- PAGE (definition/declaration): ahc_echo calls strlen(PAGE) and passes PAGE to MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static. To determine whether strlen(PAGE) is safe (no out-of-bounds access) we must know how PAGE is defined (string literal, char array with explicit size, binary buffer without terminator, etc.). If PAGE is not null-terminated or its declared size is smaller than the semantic length, strlen could read past the object bounds.

- DENIED (definition/declaration): ahc_echo calls strlen(DENIED) and passes DENIED to MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static. Same rationale as PAGE — we must confirm DENIED is a properly null-terminated string or that its storage and declared size guarantee strlen will not access beyond the object.

- MY_OPAQUE_STR (definition/declaration): MY_OPAQUE_STR is passed to MHD_queue_auth_required_response3. That callee (or other downstream code) may use standard string.h functions on the opaque string (e.g., strcpy/strlen/strcmp). To ensure no out-of-bounds string access, we need the exact definition/type and storage/termination of MY_OPAQUE_STR.

- Prototype/definition of MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static: ahc_echo uses this function with strlen(...) results. We need the prototype/implementation contract to know whether this function expects a NUL-terminated C string or an explicit buffer/length, whether it will call string.h functions internally, or whether it copies/reads the buffer in a way that could cause additional bounds assumptions. That affects whether passing PAGE or DENIED as done here is safe.

- Prototype/definition of MHD_queue_auth_required_response3: ahc_echo calls this with realm and MY_OPAQUE_STR. This function may internally use string.h routines on realm/opaque string (copying, concatenation, etc.). Knowing its prototype/behavior clarifies whether it requires NUL-terminated strings and whether it could cause out-of-bounds accesses on those arguments.

- Prototype/definition of MHD_digest_auth_check3: ahc_echo passes realm, username and password to this function. Although username/password/realm are local string literals here, the callee may use string.h functions on them (or on other strings derived from them). Having the prototype/behavior lets the analyzer determine whether any string operations inside that function could violate bounds given the arguments supplied.

Notes:
- The local username/password/realm in ahc_echo are defined in the function and are string literals (so normally safe), so they themselves do not need to be listed as external symbols. The items above are the additional external symbols and API contracts needed to determine whether the strlen and the downstream uses of strings can cause accesses beyond object bounds in accordance with the MISRA rule.
